action.action-desc: Mr. Huffman introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To amend title 23, United States Code, to require transportation planners to consider projects and strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Generating Resilient, Environmentally Exceptional National Streets Act or the GREEN Streets Act.
Section 150 of title 23, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (b)—

subparagraph.text: by redesignating paragraph (7) as paragraph (8); and
by inserting after paragraph (6) the following:

paragraph.text: To reduce carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions and improve the resilience of the transportation system.
in subsection (c)—

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (1)—

clause.text: by striking the paragraph designation and all that follows through Not later and inserting the following:

subparagraph.text: Not later

clause.text: by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall periodically update the rulemaking promulgated under subparagraph (A) as necessary, including to implement the amendments made to this section by the GREEN Streets Act.
in paragraph (5)—

clause.text: in subparagraph (A), by striking and at the end;
in subparagraph (B), by striking the period at the end and inserting ; and; and
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: transit accessibility (as defined in section 5326(a) of title 49);
transit stop distance (as defined in section 5326(a) of title 49); and
transit mode share (as defined in section 5326(a) of title 49).
by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: For the purpose of carrying out section 119(f)(3), the Secretary shall establish—

subparagraph.text: minimum standards for States to use in decreasing per capita vehicle miles traveled on public roads, including through—

clause.text: alignment of zoning and land use policy and planning;
investment in active and safe transportation infrastructure, such as sidewalks, trails, and bike lanes;
public transit and safe multimodal access to public transit; and
intercity passenger service by train or bus;

subparagraph.text: minimum standards for States to use in improving the resilience of public roads;

in consultation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, minimum standards for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions on public roads, with the goal of achieving net-zero emissions; and
measures for States to use to assess—

clause.text: carbon dioxide emissions on public roads;
air pollutants and multipollutants on public roads, including noise pollution; and
any other greenhouse gas emissions on public roads, as determined to be appropriate by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: in subsection (d)(1)—

subparagraph.text: by striking subsection (c), each State shall set and inserting subsection (c)(1)(A), and not later than 1 year after each update of that rulemaking under subsection (c)(1)(B), each State shall set or update, as applicable,; and
by striking and (6) and inserting (6), and (7).

section.header: Analysis for road capacity expansion projects

paragraph.text: Section 134(h) of title 23, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (1)—

clause.text: by redesignating subparagraphs (F) through (J) as subparagraphs (H) through (L), respectively; and
by inserting after subparagraph (E) the following:

subparagraph.text: reduce carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions;
decrease per capita vehicle miles traveled;
by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.header: Analysis of projects that increase traffic capacity

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph:

clause.text: The term covered project means a project that—

subclause.text: uses funds made available under this title to increase traffic capacity, including—

item.text: by adding new travel lanes, including on an existing road; or
by converting shoulder lanes into new travel lanes; or

subclause.text: is projected to receive not less than $25,000,000 of Federal funds made available under this title.

clause.text: The term environmental justice community means a community with significant representation of communities of color, low-income communities, or Tribal and Indigenous communities, that experiences, or is at risk of experiencing, higher or more adverse human health or environmental effects.

subparagraph.text: In furtherance of the planning goals described in subparagraphs (F) and (G) of paragraph (1), a metropolitan planning organization, with input from local community-based organizations with relevant expertise, shall conduct and publish an analysis of—

clause.text: the impact on per capita vehicle miles traveled, mobile source greenhouse gas emissions, and non-single-occupancy-vehicle trips, including trips by bicycle, pedestrian travel, public transportation, and passenger rail, prior to approval of each covered project within the metropolitan planning area; and

with respect to environmental justice communities served by the metropolitan planning organization, air pollution, toxic air contaminants, and other environmental justice metrics measured by a Federal environmental justice tool, such as the environmental justice mapping and screening tool created by the Environmental Protection Agency.

paragraph.text: Before carrying out a project to construct new capacity for single occupancy passenger vehicles, a metropolitan planning organization shall submit to the Secretary and make publicly available documents that demonstrate—

subparagraph.text: that the metropolitan planning organization has shown progress in achieving a state of good repair on the National Highway System, as defined in the asset management plan of the State under section 119(e);
that the project—

clause.text: supports the achievement of performance targets of the State established under section 150; and
is more cost effective, as determined by a benefit-cost analysis, than—

subclause.text: an operational improvement to the facility or corridor;
the construction of a public transportation project eligible for assistance under chapter 53 of title 49; or
the construction of a non-single occupancy passenger vehicle project that improves freight movement; and

subparagraph.text: that the metropolitan planning organization and the owner of the facility have a public plan for maintaining and operating the new asset while continuing progress in achieving a state of good repair as described in subparagraph (A).

section.header: Investment requirements to meet performance goals
section.text: Section 119(f) of title 23, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in the subsection heading, by striking conditions and inserting conditions; greenhouse gas emissions on public roads; and
by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.header: Greenhouse gas emissions on public roads

clause.text: Subject to clause (ii), if a State reports, in a performance target report under section 150(e), that the State has not achieved the targets of the State for performance measures described in section 150(d) pertaining to the minimum standards for public roads established by the Secretary under section 150(c)(7), the State shall be required, during the following fiscal year—

subclause.text: to obligate 33 percent of the amount apportioned to the State under section 104(b)(1) for the purpose of achieving the targets through projects described in clause (iii); and

to obligate 10 percent of the amount apportioned to the State under section 104(b)(2) (other than amounts suballocated to metropolitan areas and other areas of the State under section 133(d)) for the purpose of achieving the targets through projects described in clause (iii).

clause.text: For each fiscal year after the date of enactment of this paragraph that the State does not achieve the targets of the State for performance measures described in section 150(d) pertaining to the minimum standards for public roads established by the Secretary under section 150(c)(7), the amount required to be obligated under clause (i)(I) shall be increased by 2 percent over the amount required to be obligated in the previous fiscal year.
A project referred to in clause (i) is any of the following:

subclause.text: A project on a Federal-aid highway.
Transit expansion, including an expansion of regular bus routes, arterial bus rapid transit, highway bus rapid transit, rail transit, and intercity passenger rail.
Transit service improvements, including an increased service level.
Transit fare reduction or transit priority treatments.
A project for active transportation infrastructure.
A project for micromobility infrastructure and service, including shared vehicle services.
A land use project, including residential and other density increases, mixed-use development, and transit-oriented development.

subparagraph.text: The obligation requirement in subparagraph (A)(i)(I) for a fiscal year shall remain in effect for each subsequent fiscal year until the date on which the Secretary determines that the State has achieved the targets of the State for performance measures described in section 150(d) pertaining to the minimum standards for public roads established by the Secretary under section 150(c)(7).

subsection.text: Section 5326 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in the section heading, by inserting and accessibility after management;
in subsection (a)—

subparagraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (2) and (3) as paragraphs (5) and (6), respectively;
by inserting after paragraph (1) the following:

paragraph.text: The term covered entity means—

subparagraph.text: any metropolitan planning area with a population of not fewer than 250,000 individuals on the date of enactment of the GREEN Streets Act; and
any State in which there exists a metropolitan planning area with a population of not fewer than 250,000 individuals on the date of enactment of the GREEN Streets Act.

paragraph.text: The term first last mile accessibility means the requirement of a traveler to travel—

subparagraph.text: from the starting point of their journey to the place of transportation; and
from place of transportation to their final destination.

paragraph.text: The term transit accessibility means the share of jobs, health care facilities, grocery stores and other food suppliers, schools, and other destinations accessible by public transportation in any 45-minute period.

subparagraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The term transit mode share means the percentage of trips taken by public transportation for both commuting and noncommuting trips.
The term transit stop distance means the average distance by census block to the nearest transit stop, passenger station, or terminal providing regularly scheduled service.
by redesignating subsections (c) and (d) as subsections (d) and (e), respectively; and
by inserting after subsection (b) the following:
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the GREEN Streets Act, the Secretary shall establish national transit access standards and performance measures for—

subparagraph.text: transit accessibility;
transit stop distance;
transit mode share;
first last mile accessibility; and
accessibility for individuals with disabilities in accordance with guidance issued by the Access Board on accessibility for transportation vehicles, streets, and sidewalks.

paragraph.text: Not later than 180 days after the date on which the Secretary establishes the standards and performance measures under paragraph (1), the Secretary shall—

subparagraph.text: require each covered entity to—

clause.text: establish targets for the covered entity relating to each of the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1); and
submit to the Secretary a report describing—

subclause.text: the performance of the covered entity with respect to each of the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1); and
by functional classification, the share of housing units and roadways in the covered entity that have—

item.text: other forms of dedicated nonmotorized facilities; and

subparagraph.text: provide technical assistance, including analytical tools, to assist a covered entity in—

clause.text: establishing targets under subparagraph (A)(i); and
reporting on performance under subparagraph (A)(ii).

subsection.text: The analysis for chapter 53 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking the item relating to section 5326 and inserting the following:
Section 5326(c) of title 49, United States Code (as amended by section 5(a)(4)), is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: Not later than 180 days after receipt of the initial report under paragraph (2)(A)(ii), the Secretary shall establish a schedule for the submission of subsequent reports by each covered entity.
Each subsequent report under this paragraph shall describe—

clause.text: the progress of the covered entity in meeting the targets of the covered entity relating to the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1), including any change in performance since the submission of the previous report;
any revision of existing targets or establishment of new targets relating to the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1); and
any proposal for the revision of existing targets or the establishment of new targets relating to the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1).

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall provide technical assistance, including analytical tools, to assist a covered entity in—

clause.text: reporting on performance under this paragraph; and
establishing or revising performance targets relating to the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1).

subparagraph.text: With respect to any State or community that is not a covered entity, including a rural community or Tribal community, the Secretary shall provide technical assistance, including analytical tools, to assist those entities with reaching each of the standards and performance measures described in paragraph (1).
Nothing in subparagraph (A) requires any entity described in that subparagraph to comply with the standards, performance measures, or reporting requirements under this subsection.
